comments.commentBody: ehsandias - I share your sentiments about Nate and his role. I could not fault Nate's data and conclusions so I felt serene as we waited for the states to be called. And he was right.
Aw, we'll fly to you, CME, and we can all drink a toast to Nate Silver!

@Brian Sussman (New Rochelle, NY)
Don`t you think that the same problem has USA with his all minorities nation ( natives indians, hispanic comunity, afro-americans, etc. ) ? Maybe we should boycot USA if the americans are so smart ppl and they give advises to everybody ...
Thanks Nate, you kept a lot of people sane.

Wonder when the GOP will get it that going all Tea Party will not win elections! Denying women hard-fought rights will not win elections! Rejecting a compassionate immigration policy will not win elections. Treating half the country-- seniors, veterans and disabled--as mooches will not win elections! When will GOP learn that tax cuts with no way to pay for them are not a winning strategy?

Romney will be the fall guy, but it's the hard-right policies that lost this one.
Thank you Nate. For your insights for all these months.....You rock dude...Joe Scorborugh owes you one....

Great countywide numbers coming out of Florida:

Orange 99% in

Barack Obama
59% 262,775
Mitt Romney
41% 182,352

Hillsborough 100% in

Barack Obama
53% 278,083
Mitt Romney
46% 243,914

Pinellas 100% in

MittRomney

These three districts are swing in FL, and how they go tends to portend how the rest of the state is going to go. That Obama leads in all three does not bode well for Romney.

Then, in heavy Dem districts, we have the following:

Mitt Romney

Mitt Romney

These are all very good signs for the Obama campaign.
Good Job Nate, I have been stalking this site for the past month. Good job.

Nate,
Thank you so much for your wisdom and clarity. Congratulations on your incredibly accurate predictions - wow.

The term limit for president was set way back in HST's day. He was entitled to run a second time although he had served almost two terms and chose not to do so. Short terms for congressmen can prove to be counterproductive. As the Man has said so many times,"We have term limits; it's called a general election." :-)

I love this comment.  It's positive, definitely on topic, and useful.  It isn't up to any one president to change the country; it is about all of us understanding what we each need to do to fix our own problems, as much as possible. (The Republicans are right about the attitude toward dependency on govt.)  If it is trading down for a little while (doing this myself), so be it. Our worth is not measured in our jobs alone. If a less prestigous jobs means a boy has a working dad (provided it is a living wage), it's wonderful and wise.  That said, I am sorry to hear that your don't have help with your son.  Hope that changes.
Serious election reform would help. Really need to overturn Citizens United. That would be a very good start.

Always refreshing to check the NYT comment board and be reminded that there still are thoughtful, compassionate, enthusiastic folks out there. Whew!

What I don't understand, though, is how the House will continue to be so polarized, and so dominated by Republicans, despite Obama's win. Thoughts, anyone? Time to re-draw district lines and re-introduce bona fide competitive races?

And congratulations, Nate Silver! Once again, an A+ for the rationality of your approach and your rare ability to make complicated work available to those of us who never gamble or play poker.

2 elections called almost to the last voter. Your column was the caviar and champagne of this Velveeta and crackers election year.

Congratulations on your property tax increase! That's great news. Yeah, keep those taxes increasing. That's the secret to happiness, until they begin to take away from your spendable income, and we never pull out of this happy little recession because nobody can spend anymore. How joyous!

The only bummer is Bachmann is still in the House.  So while we'd all like to congratulate ourselves on overcoming ignorance and getting to the right solution, we still obviously have almost half of our population that still believes the lies and fallacies.  This is what We the People need to put a stop to.

I don't think I've ever lived through an election night that had such overwhelmingly good results across the board!

President Obama was re-elected. Elizabeth Warren and Tammy Baldwin were elected. Todd Akin and Richard Mourdock were defeated. Plutocrats like Mitt Romney, Linda McMahon, and Sheldon Adelson were unable to buy the government they wanted. Even my local school district property tax measure passed. It's a wonderful night! Hopefully I'll wake up tomorrow to find that California outlawed capital punishment. That would be the icing on the cake.

Congratulations, President Obama! And thank you.

As a grad student intern in the early 1970's, I counseled with college students with unplanned pregnancies. Most, thankfully, had emotional support from their partners in dealing with their decision to terminate a pregnancy.

At that time, they had to travel out-of-state for a legal abortion. The women, having scant funds, went alone with only the emotional support of clinic staff.

Birth control had not been widely available to women, and the "pill" was new. The gop agenda would prohibit hormonal, i.u.d., and abortifacient methods-- the very ones women control themselves.

Without legal abortion, women face grim realities. Women with stable lives could choose to continue a pregnancy, but poor or marginally employed women are trapped. A woman must be able to make decisions for her life.

I worked with impoverished mothers on Chicago's South Side. Reagan's "welfare queen" was a slanderous jab at women struggling with limited means and education. Where was his heart ?

Racism remains politically expedient; a door is now opening for theocracy to slip into our homes. Both are political power ploys.

These extremists would force their religious beliefs on women and then deny a family any safety net. A 'thousand points of light" will provide food, housing, and medical care ? It is total deceit to claim charities are the solution.

This is an outrageous throwback to women as chattel with no right to self-determination.

This juggernaut must be stopped now !

People who believe that their political (and personal) opinions reflect the commands of the omniscient, omnipotent ruler of the universe are much less likely to honestly try to strike a balance with those who disagree with them--which is what we expect our political representatives to do. It should be extremely relevant to us whether a candidate holds an opinion because of thoughtful reflection or because they think they've received a message from the infinite (as Michelle Bachmann claimed led her into politics). You can't engage in normal political give-and-take with people who think their policies have the backing of the almighty. Such people may belong in pulpits and on op-ed boards, but we should be leery of placing them in public office. That's why candidates' religious beliefs should be open to question.

Rep. Ryan said in response to a question during the debate with Vice President Biden:

"I don't see how a person can separate their public life from their private life or from their faith. Our faith informs us in everything we do. My faith informs me about how to take care of the vulnerable, about how to make sure that people have a chance in life. Now, you want to ask basically why I'm pro-life? It's not simply because of my Catholic faith. That's a factor, of course, but ... ."

The substance of what Ryan is saying is that he views public office as a way that one private agenda achieves dominance over the others. When in office, he will make the government what he is when he is in private: he "doesn't see" how one can do otherwise.

This view appears to me to characterize his and his party's general approach, including but going beyond religion and abortion.

An alternative view is that office holders should stand back from any single religion or individual point of view and try to find common ground -- the "public interest." That's a scientific approach to public policy. Admittedly, it's harder than representing the canned policy of a single point of view.

But some try. What Biden said in response to the same question was: "I just refuse to impose that [my religion] on others, unlike my friend here, the congressman."

How is it possible for a true Christian to so deeply believe that God intends RAPE to happen, but God does NOT intend to provide support in the form of medical procedure to help heal the wound called "abortion" AFTER a rape happens. What kind of arrogance allows someone in political office to declare where God draws the line on taking care of her flock?

It's time that politicians gave up being both preachers and doctors, and just came to understand the first amendment to the USConstitution is the key to diverse people living together in peace. They can believe what they want, but they can't and shouldn't make other people believe it.

I am a woman. I was raised but am no longer a Catholic for a variety of reasons but mostly for their continued subjugation of women as evidenced by such things as their exclusion of women from the priesthood, and their recent dealings with the Leadership Conference of Women Religious.

But I also understand the Catholic belief in the sanctity of life and their belief that all abortion is murder, regardless of the circumstances. I frankly have respect for this Catholic belief, even though I don't believe it myself, as I don"t equate it with the subjugation of women.

Conversely, I am disgusted by those (men) who don't believe in a woman's right to abortion except in the case of rape, incest, and if the mother's life is in danger. I believe their position is directly connected to the subjugation of women. These men profess to believe in the sanctity of all life, yet have decided there are particular circumstances under which it would be OK to kill the fetus. Apparently women are incapable of deciding for themselves under which circumstances this would be OK.

Mourdock, by making his religious statements on the floor of the United States Senate, basically stood in defiance of our constitution. For some time, we had separation of religion and state, but clearly Mourdock and Ryan and Romney and Atkins (all the rest, too?), appear to not understand the U.S. Constitution, and why it us written to contain such great ideas.

Perhaps they should be kept out of office, until they can figure it out. Let's not have the Christian Taliban running the country.

In stating his interpretation of his god's intent on the floor of the U.S. Senate, he violate the separation of religion and state, as guaranteed in the U.S. Constitution.  Perhaps the good senator, along with all of those promoting legislation on these grounds (Atkins, Ryan, Romney, etc....) should take some time off and review the constitution and think about why such ideas are written.

I believe that Ms. Ellington's comments from Salt Lake (above) are important, in re to Romney's belief that his candidacy is God's will.  There is a vast difference between a religion that teaches ethics and morals and a religion that annoints a particular human as the vessel for God's will.  That is what frightens me about Romney's candidacy.  Some of Obama's actions can be questioned on the basis of morals or even ethics (like targeting enemies for death or the use of drones), but Obama has not portrayed himself as God.  A Newsweek article tried to claim that he wants to be King.  I believe he has decided to use more executive power, but not as a King or a God.  Some may disagree, but I will still go for Obama as the kind of leader who is more receptive to democratic leadership.

Any exception for rape is scary.
Now husbands and boyfriends who have partners that cannot or don't want to carry a child will have to label themselves rapists. And if unwilling to do so voluntarily, may be accused to be rapists by their partners in order to obtain an abortion.

Is it better to become a felon than lose respect and love of your partner?

I am  a male and I believe in a woman's right to choose. It is not the business of government or anyone else to decide whether or not a woman has an abortion. I take issue with your depiction of the god of Abraham as a male. I had thought that once Jews, followed by Christians, followed by Muslims decided on the one god theory then gender no longer applied.. Why should this god be a male or a female? It makes no sense to assign a gender to the god of Abraham. Orthodox Jews today tend to use the Term 'Hashem' or 'The One' which at least avoids specifying a gender even if it is basically meaningless.

The people who actually run the GOP couldn't care less about the 'social issues' like abortion and rape. They use it as a diversion from their ignorant members of the proletariat who vote Republican. This diverst them from the real issues:

The merger of corporate interests (e.g., the Koch Bro's...) with the federal government. The real Republicans brokerd throw in Christ and religion to convince to an even greater degree. If Christ knew what is going on in his name -- he'd come back and throw the money changers out of the temple.
